DOC.HEAD: Decision to Strike Against Noriega Made on Sunday, White House Says
With PM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush made up his mind Sunday to launch the U.S. military strike against Panama's Manuel Antonio Noriega, barely 24 hours after the slaying of an American Marine officer outside Noriega's military headquarters in Panama City, the White House said. Bush administration officials kept their plans secret until Tuesday evening when news organizations began reporting heavy U.S. military flights into Panama, where the United States has 12,000 troops based to protect the Panama Canal. Even as the Pentagon was preparing the effort to capture Noriega and allow Panamanian opposition leaders to take over the government, Bush went as planned Tuesday evening to a White House Christmas party for 300 friends, administration officials, White House staff and reporters. The president maintained silence Sunday when asked for his reaction to the killing of the unarmed Marine lieutenant, who was trying to escape a Panamanian Defense Force checkpoint after a wrong turn brought him and three other U.S. soldiers close to Noriega's headquarters. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, in an early morning briefing today announcing the move against Noriega, said Bush ``has been considering this matter for several days.'' He said the president ``was quite disturbed'' by the killing of the Marine officer and harassment of a naval officer and his wife by Panamanian soldiers at the same checkpoint. ``The president reviewed this issue with his national security advisers on Sunday afternoon. They considered options, developed a plan and the president made the basic decision to proceed with this action,'' Fitzwater said. He added that there had been ``any number of meetings'' since Sunday, but emphasized, ``there really has not been any question about our willingness or our readiness to proceed since that time.'' The White House on Sunday deplored the killing of the Marine and said the incident was a ``consequence'' of the outlaw Noriega regime, imposed on Panama against ``the will of the Panamanian people'' who voted in May to elect opposition leader Guillermo Endara to the presidency. Noriega, Panama's military commander and de facto ruler, nullified those elections. On Friday a legislature of Noriega cronies declared the country in a state of war against the United States and named Noriega its ``maximum'' leader. Bush, in an interview Monday with The Associated Press and other wire services, expressed ``enormous frustration ... that the democratic system that was voted on in Panama was totally put down by force.'' He called the killing of the Marine ``an enormous outrage,'' and pointedly refused to rule out a military response. Bush had no public events on his schedule Tuesday except the Christmas party, where he and wife Barbara gaily posed with each guest for pictures in front of an enormous tree, decorated with dolls from children's stories and fables. Bush stayed to hear an Army chorus sing carols in the East Room, hoisting up 3-year-old granddaughter Nancy Ellis LeBlond in his arms for a better view and extending a hearty handshake to former White House press secretary Jim Brady, wounded in the 1981 assassination attempt against former President Reagan. At the Pentagon, military public information officers also sought not to tip their hand. Most left their offices at the regular quitting time Tuesday evening. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, his deputy Robert Gates and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu all put in brief appearances at the Christmas party Tuesday night before shuttling back to their offices to wait for the U.S. military strike. Bush stayed in the Oval Office until 4:05 a.m. EST, when he retired to his personal residence for a brief sleep before a 7 a.m. address to the nation from the Oval Office.
